Posts.Content: May 8, 2011 05:35AM CarylC wrote: I had an echocardiogram for Herceptin but no other scans.  I saw 3 different oncs and they all said "we don't chase cancer, that's why you are getting chemo."  They assume there is some floating around from the biopsy, surgery, nodes, etc., but the chemo and rads will take care of it. I'm kind of glad.  My dad, who has small cell lung cancer, had some spots show up in his back.  First they dx'd an infection, then they dx'd it as cancer, now they are saying they think it might just be arthritis.  I don't think I could go through that emotional up and down and up again!
Posts.Title: Scans - What did your doc suggest? DebRox annettek

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 08:31PM CarylC wrote: Sorry, I can't really help you other than to say I totally understand!  My story is pretty similar and I go Thursday for my stereotactic in both breasts.   I will be thinking of you tomorrow.  I hope everything goes well for you!

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2011 08:23AM CarylC wrote: @ Pandazankar They are stretchy so probably forgivable to quite a degree.  I buy a medium and wear tops from small to medium. I didn't want anything too tight around my chest. @ Erica - the water enhancers I use are not the gel clear ones but the fabric covered ones.  I've  not had any luck with the other ones.  Sears sells the same ones as Wal Mart does for twice the price.  I haven't seen the fabric ones at my Target.
Posts.Title: Is it time for prosthesis? cinnamonsmiles cinnamonsmiles

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2011 08:00AM CarylC wrote: I had my bi-mx in March and also found the nerve pain horrible but wearing something against my chest for several weeks definitely helped.  I did not get fitted for anything, I've cobbled together my own personal very inexpensive and lightweight options that I like, but now I can wear or not wear whatever I choose.  I did think I would never be able to wear prosthetics because of the pain but found that compressing the area with something for that period of time helped me heal much better. Yesterday I had to go for a bone scan and I went flat and the woman doing the test asked me if I had had surgery and when I replied yes, asked was it a lumpectomy, uni or bi-lateral.  She then remarked "the scarf makes it hard to tell."   I felt great although I had totally forgotten that I was flat anyway.
Posts.Title: Is it time for prosthesis? cinnamonsmiles cinnamonsmiles

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2011 09:47PM CarylC wrote: Erica, I buy a bra from Sears, it's the Apostrophe brand ($20) "shadow stripe" comes in xs, s, m, l and xl and has little pads in it so it already has pockets.  Then I buy the "water" breast enhancers from Walmart and turn them upside down and put them in the pockets.  Done.  The whole thing weighs less than my old Vicky's Secret bras used to weigh and the bras come in all kinds of colors.  They are cut high like a camisole, so there is no gapping when you bend over.  The breast enhancers are about $5 at Wal Mart and the bras are on sale all the time for $14.   My sister saw me in a tight tank top Saturday for the first time and was like "wow!"  I wear the A/B enhancers but they also come in C/D as well.
Posts.Title: Is it time for prosthesis? cinnamonsmiles cinnamonsmiles

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2011 09:16PM CarylC wrote: Dawn - you look gorgeous! I've got to admit, I like being bald.. . . takes 2 seconds to get ready every day, saves a ton of money on products and I don't have to worry about what the weather is like, just a bit of soap and go!  I think I may keep it super super short when it starts coming back.  I'm just really liking it.  I dread having to go back to taking care of hair again . . .
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 02:14PM CarylC wrote: got a call today from my doctor, DCIS, extensive, high grade with little hints of micro invasion, whatever the heck that means, MRI next and she isn't sure why the radiologist didn't go ahead with the biopsy on both breasts either . . . seems like everything is so laissez-faire . . .  I need something concrete right now to hold on to.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy question CarylC CarylC

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 07:46PM CarylC wrote: Hi, Silia.  It's still sore a bit, like when I roll over without a bra on,and it's painful to the touch but it's so much better!  The bruising is horrific though.  The radiologist's office did tell me that one of the biopsy sites bled a bit more than most people do, so that may be why it still hurts or why it is as colorful as it is!
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy question CarylC CarylC

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 08:02PM CarylC wrote: Had my biopsy today.  After doing 24 samples out of the right breast, the doctor decided not to do the 2nd breast.  I could have stood it, I'm not sure why he changed his mind . . . he said something about an MRI would give us more information.   I should have results on Monday.  I hate waiting through the weekend.   The procedure wasn't as bad as I thought but I'm in a lot of pain now!
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy question CarylC CarylC

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2011 08:04AM CarylC wrote: This is such a timely topic for me.  First it was "just" DCIS so that was a good thing and I should be happy.  Then it was "just" 2 micro invasions and my BS said it was nothing to worry about.  Now it's stage IIb and everyone keeps telling me how "stage II is not a death sentance" and I know all this and I'm not pouting, I'm laughing, joking, back to work one week after my bi-lat mx, but damn it, sometimes I feel like I should get to be sad over this "good" prognosis.  It's still cancer, any way you dissect it and you get to feel however you want to feel and that is OKAY.  One of my friends bought me a shirt that says "remember kids, Cancer sucks" and somedays you just can't escape that feeling.   I've decided I'm just going to "be."
Posts.Title: Depression Over Good Prognosis? huntreiter3 Momine

Posts.Content: CarylC wrote: I am scheduled for a biopsy on Thursday.  The doctor says they have to do 2 sections each in each breast and he doesn't think I will be able to handle it all at one time.  I don't want to have to go twice, take off of work twice, wait for results twice, etc. Anyone else done both breasts on the same day?    Dx 3/11/2011, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIB, Grade 2, 3/12 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy question CarylC CarylC

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2011 09:05PM CarylC wrote: Rose, I feel for you!  I went in for my BMX with a dx of DCIS and came out Stage IIb with positive nodes, lymphovascular invasion and extracapsular extension.  It wasn't fun to wake up to find out I'd be having chemo and radiation.  I'd thought I'd traded having my breasts removed to avoid all that!   Now, 9 months later, I'm doing radiation, just ran a 5K yesterday and I'm hanging in there.  You will too!  It's all doable, although none of it is fun.
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2011 10:07PM CarylC wrote: Add me, bilateral on March 10th. No immed reconstruction, will think about that later.
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2011 02:04PM CarylC wrote: I agree with the majority above but I had no reconstruction which I think makes a big difference!.  I didn't use the morphine in the hospital at all - except to have my drains taken out and I was lucky because I came home with no drains.  Sleeping at first was a little hard to get used to, but I was back at work a week after my bi-lateral mx with just tylenol as needed and on my motorcycle 3 weeks out.  It certainly wasn't fun and I wouldn't want to do it again but it is doable.  Doing my arm exercises was more painful than recovering from surgery.
Posts.Title: how painful mastectomy is and how do you cope up with it? h0petoBC Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 09:56AM CarylC wrote: I am almost 36 hours post-op.  The pain isn't bad except for when I move!  It does feel like a truck ran over my ribcage and armpits.  Other than occasionally reaching too far and feeling a staple pull - which hurts like hell - it hasn't been that bad.  I only used the morphine pump 2 or 3 times and that was more to fall asleep.  Right now I'm taking 1/2 of a vicodin.  I got a fever and am still in the hospital but hope to go home today.  Woke up after surgery to find out my lymph nodes were not clean and I will be getting chemo after all.
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2011 04:14PM CarylC wrote: Kezzie - glad you are home and feeling well!  I only took pain pills to help me sleep at night, I didn't really hurt but I had this "pinching" phantom feeling that drove me nuts! My drains were both gone before I came home. Hope everyday is a better one!
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2011 10:15AM CarylC wrote: What is your doctor suggesting?  Mine said mx period.  Multi-focal disease meant the whole thing was coming off.  Multi focal DCIS on the other side, to  me, meant take that one too - I didn't want to deal with waiting and watching and preferred to be even if it meant flat.   You can get a 2nd opinion if you are not sure if you agree with the first doctor.  The bottom line will be to do what feels right to you based on the advice you get from the professionals.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy vs. Masectomy three17 annettek

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 07:44PM CarylC wrote: Hi, all.  Hope everyone is doing well.  Tomorrow will be my 2-week post op anniversary.  I've been back at work since Monday.  I'm not doing recon so my recovery is probably much easier.  No real pain except in my arms when stretching my muscles and some irritation where clothes rub against my sensitive skin.   I have had to go back to the BS twice to have fluid drained.  Tomorrow I finally meet with an oncologist to see what the next step in the program will be.
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 05:45PM CarylC wrote: Asto, I had my bi-mx on the 10th and I still can't wear any type of bra.  I can wear camisoles or tank tops only.  Anything that puts pressure on the center of my chest, even a too-tight tank is too much.  It does make it hard to get dressed for work.  Hopefully it will go away eventually.
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 09:34PM CarylC wrote: That's what I thought too - I thought I was trading my breasts in exchange for no other treatments!  However, we didn't know at that time that there was nodal involvement, according to the oncologist.  The nodes were "macrometastes" not "micro" (not sure I spelled that right) and I remember them being measured in cm - although I gave my pathology report to oncologist so can't double check.  Also I do know there was extracapsular extension, although I'm not sure that has anything to do with it or not.  I do know that oncologist today said I was very lucky it was only 3 and not 4, because 4 puts you in a whole different ball game.  At this point, I guess it doesn't matter if I do one, two or 3 kinds of treatment, they all suck as far as I'm concerned.  Might as well do it all and make sure I'm safe if I have to do any of them!  The doctors are at the University of Chicago and the lead doctor specializes in HER2+ breast cancer so I'm hopeful they know what they are doing!
Posts.Title: Stage II Forum rumoret NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 07:29PM CarylC wrote: SpecialK, I asked them today how many rounds of chemo, once a week, every three weeks for 6 rounds.  Then asked why radiation, they said because of the nodes, but I didn't ask them where - didn't even think of that question.  They said always rads with nodes.  Is this not common?  These are University of Chicago doctors, who are doing research on HER2 positive cancer, which is why I went there.
Posts.Title: Stage II Forum rumoret NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 08:16AM CarylC wrote: I met with an oncologist for the first time yesterday.  Bi-mx was 2 weeks ago.  I knew I'd be getting chemo, but thought with a mx that I wouldn't need rads.  She's saying a round of chemo, then Herceptin for a year and rads after chemo is over.  Chemo will be TCH or something like that, once a week every 3 weeks but she didn't say for how many rounds and I forgot to ask!  Ugh!  My nodes did have extracapular extension but I would think the chemo would kill whatever cancer cells may have escaped from there, so I'm assuming the radiation if for my breast but since it was taken out and I believe I had great margins, I'm surprised. Anyone else doing this same route?
Posts.Title: Stage II Forum rumoret NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2011 09:35PM CarylC wrote: I don't know about forms but my local prosthetic place just told me that if I want extra bras above what my insurance plan will pay for, they will sell them to me at the same price the insurance plan pays (which is about $20-$40 cheaper per bra than what the other local stores have them priced at.) That seemed pretty fair to me.  My insurance company covers forms and bras as "medically needed" but if over $700 per year, you need approval.  That turned out to be a pair of forms - I had a BMX - and 6 bras from my provider.
